title: JL1-CD: A New Benchmark for Remote Sensing Change Detection and a Robust Multi-Teacher Knowledge Distillation Framework
author: Ziyuan Liu (Beijing National Research Center for Information Science and Technology), Ruifei Zhu (Chang Guang Satellite Technology Co., Ltd.), Long Gao (Chang Guang Satellite Technology Co., Ltd.), Yuanxiu Zhou (Chang Guang Satellite Technology Co., Ltd.), Jingyu Ma (Chang Guang Satellite Technology Co., Ltd.), Yuantao Gu (Beijing National Research Center for Information Science and Technology)
relevance_why: The introduction of a new dataset for change detection could inform future research in audio event detection, particularly in multimodal contexts.
background: Change detection in remote sensing involves identifying differences in the state of an object or phenomenon by comparing satellite images taken at different times.
contribution: This paper introduces the JL1-CD dataset and a Multi-Teacher Knowledge Distillation framework to enhance the performance of change detection models in remote sensing, achieving state-of-the-art results.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods often rely on limited datasets and may not generalize well across different scenarios, particularly in dynamic environments.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by introducing a large-scale, high-resolution dataset paired with a robust knowledge distillation framework that adapts to various change area ratios (CAR).

key_innovation: The method uniquely combines a partitioning strategy based on CAR with a multi-teacher knowledge distillation approach, enabling better model training and inference efficiency.
real_world_impact: By providing a comprehensive benchmark and improving model accuracy, this research has the potential to enhance applications in environmental monitoring, urban planning, and disaster management.
limitations: No limitations are explicitly mentioned by the authors.

new_terms.Change Area Ratio (CAR): **Change Area Ratio (CAR)** refers to the proportion of an image that has undergone changes between two time points, which is crucial for understanding the scale of changes detected.

open_sourcing: The code is available at https://github.com/circleLZY/MTKD-CD.
